ElementDescription: The NDAR Global Unique Identifier (GUID) for research subject
Subject ID how it's defined in lab/project
Date on which the interview/genetic test/sampling/imaging/biospecimen was completed. MM/DD/YYYY
Age in months at the time of the interview/test/sampling/imaging.
Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.

ElementDescription: Sex of subject at birth
Notes: M = Male; F = Female; O=Other; NR = Not reported

ElementDescription: Timepoint/visit label
Form used/assessment name
Respondent
Respondent details
The event name for which the data was collected
Diagnosis method - responses in this form are based on diagnosis by:
Notes: 1= A Single Clinician; 2= A Formal Consensus Panel; 3= Other

ElementDescription: Does the subject have normal cognition and normal behavior?
Does the subject meet the criteria for dementia?
Based entirely on the history and examination (including neuropsychological testing), what is the cognitive/behavioral syndrome? Dementia syndrome - Amnestic multidomain dementia syndrome
Based entirely on the history and examination (including neuropsychological testing), what is the cognitive/behavioral syndrome? Dementia syndrome - Posterior cortical atrophy syndrome
Based entirely on the history and examination (including neuropsychological testing), what is the cognitive/behavioral syndrome? Dementia syndrome - Primary progressive aphasia (PPA) syndrome
PPA Syndrome Criteria
Notes: 1= Meets criteria for semantic PPA; 2= Meets criteria for logopenic PPA; 3= Meets criteria for nonfluent/agrammatic PPA; 4= PPA other/not otherwise specified

ElementDescription: Based entirely on the history and examination (including neuropsychological testing), what is the cognitive/behavioral syndrome? Dementia syndrome - Behavioral variant FTD (bvFTD) syndrome
Based entirely on the history and examination (including neuropsychological testing), what is the cognitive/behavioral syndrome? Dementia syndrome - Lewy body dementia syndrome

Based entirely on the history and examination (including neuropsychological testing), what is the cognitive/behavioral syndrome? Dementia syndrome - Non-amnestic multidomain dementia, not PCA, PPA, bvFTD, or DLB syndrome
If the subject does not have normal cognition or behavior and is not clinically demented, indicate the type of cognitive impairment below. Amnestic MCI, single domain (aMCI SD)
If the subject does not have normal cognition or behavior and is not clinically demented, indicate the type of cognitive impairment below. Amnestic MCI, multiple domains (aMCI MD)
Amnestic MCI, multiple domains (aMCI MD) - Affected Domains: Language
Amnestic MCI, multiple domains (aMCI MD) - Affected Domains: Attention
Amnestic MCI, multiple domains (aMCI MD) - Affected Domains: Executive
Amnestic MCI, multiple domains (aMCI MD) - Affected Domains: Visuospatial
If the subject does not have normal cognition or behavior and is not clinically demented, indicate the type of cognitive impairment below. Non-amnestic MCI, single domain (naMCI SD)
Non-amnestic MCI, single domain (naMCI SD) - Affected Domains: Language
Non-amnestic MCI, single domain (naMCI SD) - Affected Domains: Attention
Non-amnestic MCI, single domain (naMCI SD) - Affected Domains: Executive
Non-amnestic MCI, single domain (naMCI SD) - Affected Domains: Visuospatial
If the subject does not have normal cognition or behavior and is not clinically demented, indicate the type of cognitive impairment below. Non-amnestic MCI, multiple domains (naMCI MD)
Non-amnestic MCI, multiple domains (naMCI MD) - Affected Domains: Language
Non-amnestic MCI, multiple domains (naMCI MD) - Affected Domains: Attention
Non-amnestic MCI, multiple domains (naMCI MD) - Affected Domains: Executive
Non-amnestic MCI, multiple domains (naMCI MD) - Affected Domains: Visuospatial
If the subject does not have normal cognition or behavior and is not clinically demented, indicate the type of cognitive impairment below. Cognitively impaired, not MCI
Indicate neurodegenerative biomarker status, using local standards for positivity. Abnormally elevated amyloid on PET
Indicate neurodegenerative biomarker status, using local standards for positivity. Abnormally low amyloid in CSF
Indicate neurodegenerative biomarker status, using local standards for positivity. FDG-PET pattern of AD
Indicate neurodegenerative biomarker status, using local standards for positivity. Hippocampal atrophy
Indicate neurodegenerative biomarker status, using local standards for positivity. Tau PET evidence for AD
Indicate neurodegenerative biomarker status, using local standards for positivity. Abnormally elevated CSF tau or ptau
Indicate neurodegenerative biomarker status, using local standards for positivity. FDG-PET evidence for frontal or anterior temporal hypometabolism for FTLD
Indicate neurodegenerative biomarker status, using local standards for positivity. Tau PET evidence for FTLD
Indicate neurodegenerative biomarker status, using local standards for positivity. Structural MRI evidence for frontal or anterior temporal atrophy for FTLD
Indicate neurodegenerative biomarker status, using local standards for positivity. Dopamine transporter scan (DATscan) evidence for Lewy Body Disease
Indicate neurodegenerative biomarker status, using local standards for positivity. Other
If other for neurodegenerative biomarker status, please specify:
Is there evidence for cerebrovascular disease (CVD) on imaging? Large vessel infarct(s)
Is there evidence for cerebrovascular disease (CVD) on imaging? Lacunar infarct(s)
Is there evidence for cerebrovascular disease (CVD) on imaging? Macro hemorrhage(s)
Is there evidence for cerebrovascular disease (CVD) on imaging? Microhemorrhage(s)
Is there evidence for cerebrovascular disease (CVD) on imaging? Moderate white-matter hyperintensity
Is there evidence for cerebrovascular disease (CVD) on imaging? Extensive white-matter hyperintensity
Does the subject have a dominantly inherited AD mutation (PSEN1, PSEN2, APP)?
Does the subject have a hereditary FTLD mutation (e.g., GRN, VCP, TARBP, FUS, C9orf72, ChMP2B, MAPT)?
Does the subject have a hereditary mutation other than an AD or FTLD mutation?
If yes, to having a hereditary mutation other than an AD or FTLD mutation, please specify:

ElementDescription: Is there imaging evidence of cystic infarction in cognitive network(s)?
Notes: 0= No; 1= Yes; 9= Unknown, no relevant imaging data available

ElementDescription: Is there imaging evidence of cystic infarction, imaging evidence of extensive white matter hyperintensity, and impairment in executive function?
Notes: 0= No; 1= Yes; 9= Unknown, no relevant imaging data available
